TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who lives in GPE . She was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

The application concerns a real estate in GPE which is located in GPE . The estate had been owned DATE by PERSON , an NORP citizen who , after having married a NORP national , temporarily lost her NORP citizenship until DATE . PERSON was succeeded in DATE by Mr PERSON , an NORP bishop who died in DATE and who was succeeded on his part by PERSON , who was also an NORP citizen . The applicant inherited upon PERSON death in DATE .

After the foundation of GPE ( GDR ) , foreign assets were in general put under public administration , and the ORG powers of disposal were considerably restricted . As a consequence , the GPE went into bilateral negotiations with GPE ( among them GPE ) over financial and property issues . In DATE , the GPE concluded several Lump Sum Agreements ( Globalentschädigungsabkommen ) . A Lump Sum Agreement with GPE was concluded on CARDINAL DATE according to which the parties agreed that the GPE would pay to GPE a certain lump sum in order to settle property claims of GPE as well as of NORP citizens and legal persons . The last rate of the lump sum was paid in DATE by GPE ( ORG ) as the legal successor of the GPE . The lump sum was distributed by ORG ( Bundesverteilungskommission ) in ORG on the basis of NORP law , in particular the so - called LAW ( Verteilungsgesetz DDR ) .

In DATE , Mr PERSON applied to ORG for consideration of the PERSON estate , which had been put under GPE administration in DATE , in the negotiations for the Lump Sum Agreement . Mr PERSON was informed by ORG on CARDINAL occasions in DATE and DATE that the PERSON estate was part of the negotiations to ORG .

In DATE , PERSON ( who had inherited from Mr PERSON and whom the applicant succeeded in DATE ) applied to ORG for compensation from the lump sum . Her application was dismissed on DATE . ORG found that Mr PERSON and PERSON fulfilled the conditions of NORP nationality under LAW . However , PERSON , who had been the owner of the PERSON estate when it was put under GPE administration in DATE , did not have NORP citizenship on DATE , CARDINAL of the relevant dates . The Commission reasoned that NORP nationality of PERSON as the injured person was a necessary requirement under the said legislation .

The applicant , who pursued the application after PERSON death in DATE , filed a constitutional complaint with ORG ) against the decision of ORG . ORG dismissed the application on DATE . It observed inter alia that there should be congruency between the Lump Sum Agreement and the national legislation governing the distribution . In its view , LAW met that requirement .

On DATE , upon application by ORG ( GPE PERSON Vermögensfragen ) , the real estate in GPE was allocated to the ORG in accordance with LAW ( b ) LAW ( Vermögenszuordnungsgesetz ) by order of ORG ) . LAW ( b ) LAW provides that assets for which compensation was provided for in bilateral treaties between the GPE and third states should be allocated to the ORG . The provision refers to LAW ( b ) of ORG , hereinafter the “ LAW ” ) , which excludes restitution for property losses which are covered by bilateral treaties between the GPE and third states .
The applicant who had been participating in the allocation process subsequently brought an action for annulment of the allocation order .

On DATE , ORG dismissed the applicant ’s claim and refused to grant leave to appeal on points of law . Referring to the established case law of ORG , it found that , since the purpose of LAW CARDINAL ( b ) of LAW was to avoid that GPE had to pay double compensation where damages imputable to the GPE had already been compensated . Accordingly , the only prerequisite for of LAW CARDINAL ( b ) of LAW was the asset in question had been covered by LAW . As it was based on the payment of a lump sum , it did not matter whether the individual had actually received compensation , a matter which was anyway within the sphere of ORG to the agreement with the GPE . ORG to the lump sum agreement with the GPE had protected the interests of their nationals on the international level and the international agreement , once full payment was made , finally solved all property issues covered by that agreement . ORG , having regard to the material before it , established that the PERSON estate had been covered by LAW between GPE and the GPE . In this respect , the court noted that , in the appendix to the ORG , the NORP delegation had registered the estate as a subject matter during the negotiations . It further found that the estate had been validly included , with the consent of its then owner . In this respect , ORG referred to ORG which interpreted the relevant provisions of LAW to the effect that it applied to individuals of NORP citizenship on DATE and on DATE , the date of signature , but did not require that the owner at the time when the estate was placed under public administration held NORP citizenship on DATE . The refusal of compensation from the lump sum was a matter of NORP law and the legal opinion of ORG could not be decisive for the allocation of the assets under NORP law .

On DATE , ORG dismissed the applicant ’s motion against ORG refusal to grant leave to appeal on points of law . ORG , referring to its earlier case law , confirmed that LAW ( b ) of LAW merely required that the asset in question was covered by LAW . The actual compensation on an individual basis , which in any event was subject to the domestic law of the third ORG which had received and distributed the lump sum , was not required . The purpose of LAW CARDINAL ( b ) of LAW was to avoid double compensation of financial and property losses which were attributable to the GPE but which had already been compensated by the payment of a lump sum to a third ORG . ORG took note of the fact that the applicant had neither been compensated by ORG nor had he received any restitution by GPE . However , ORG stressed that the NORP side had paid a lump sum to the NORP government for all assets which were covered by the Agreement ( including the estate in GPE ) in order to compensate individuals who had suffered material losses . The NORP side however had no influence on whether these individuals participated in the distribution of the lump sum . The applicability of an exclusion clause such as Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( b ) of LAW could not depend on whether or not ORG had in fact made payments to all individuals whose claims had been taken into account when calculating the lump sum . It could therefore not be regarded as unfair if NORP law would deny restitution to such individuals .
On DATE , ORG refused to admit the applicant ’s constitutional complaint , finding that the impugned decisions did not violate the applicant ’s right to property as guaranteed by LAW ) .

According to its ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL , the Lump Sum Agreement covers property and financial claims of GPE as well as of NORP citizens and legal persons with regard to property which was under GPE administration . LAW provides that “ NORP nationals ” within the meaning of DATE are those who had NORP citizenship on CARDINAL DATE and on DATE of the signing of the Agreement , i.e. on CARDINAL DATE . LAW provides that , if the property claimant died before LANGUAGE DATE and held NORP citizenship upon his or her death , the successor is entitled under the condition that he or she held NORP citizenship on DATE .
According to LAW , all property and financial issues covered by the Agreement were to be settled exhaustively and definitely with the payment of the lump sum .

LAW is the domestic law which corresponds to LAW . According to LAW , the term “ NORP nationals ” was defined as persons who had NORP citizenship both on DATE and on the date of the signing of the Agreement , i.e. on CARDINAL DATE . If the owner died before CARDINAL DATE and held NORP citizenship upon his or her death , the successor is entitled under the condition that he or she held NORP citizenship on DATE .

ORG , also known as LAW , entered into force on DATE and was a part of LAW . Under the terms of the LAW , LAW was to continue to subsist in the reunified GPE after the reunification of the two GPE on DATE . The aim of the LAW was to resolve disputes over property in the territory of the GPE in a way that was socially acceptable , in order to achieve permanent legal order in GPE . LAW CARDINAL ( b ) of the LAW holds :

“ This Act shall , subject to its provisions on competences and procedure , not apply to : ( ... ) ( b ) property claims which were covered by bilateral treaties between GPE and third states ( ... ) ” .
The first sentence of LAW ( b ) LAW provides :
“ Any assets which were subject to the agreements referred to in LAW ( b ) of ORG , shall be ( ... ) allocated to ORG once the payments provided for in the agreements have been made . ”
